attributes.description: This is an example of a graphite refinery, I couldn't find and good examples in the Brazil area. It's very hard to find data on such a specific kind of factory, so I'm not sure on how the workers are treated. I would assume that they are exploited just as many Chinese people are due to very low cost of manual labor. Whoever owns the company benefits greatly from this, as they get more profit from selling their product. Every graphite refinery I've come across has been owned by a bigger, multi-national company. I wouldn't be surprised if locally owned refineries just aren't a thing. Below is an example of some refined graphite.
attributes.address: 312 Provincial Rd, Luodian, Qiannan, Guizhou, China
attributes.title: Graphite Refinery

attributes.description: This is just to make the point that they do business all over the world, not just America.
attributes.title: Generic European Pencil Store?

attributes.description: Staples products are processed and shipped out to the retail stores at locations like this one.
attributes.title: Staples Distribution center

attributes.description: This is the primary type of wood used in the construction of most pencils.
attributes.address: 6706 Wendell Way, Happy Valley, CA 96007, USA
attributes.title: California Incense Cedar

attributes.description: Faber-Castell pencils are varnished. A very common varnish uses turpentine and linseed oil, the latter of which is comes from flax, which is grown in many places around the world. I'm using Russia as an example as it is the second highest linseed producing country.
attributes.title: Flax Farm (For linseed oil)

attributes.description: Faber-Castell's USA headquarters. They manage PR and marketing in the United States region. Below is one of the many promotion videos they put out. This is where the design and marketing of the pencils takes place for the US.
attributes.title: Faber-Castell USA Headquarters

attributes.description: Indian graphite mine. Graphite is mined is a few ways, two of which are the open pit and underground methods, neither of which is beneficial to the environment. See the graphite refinery description for how workers are treated and suchlike.
attributes.title: Graphite mine

attributes.description: A sri lankan graphite mine. Graphite is mined is a few ways, two of which are the open pit and underground methods, neither of which is beneficial to the environment. See the graphite refinery description for how workers are treated and suchlike.
attributes.title: Graphite mine

attributes.description: Chinese graphite mine. Graphite is mined is a few ways, two of which are the open pit and underground methods, neither of which is beneficial to the environment. See the graphite refinery description for how workers are treated and suchlike.
attributes.address: Wenfeng St, Xintai, Tai'an, Shandong, China
attributes.title: Graphite mine

attributes.description: This is an example of a way that clay is extracted from the earth -- through deforestation. There are other methods, and many more types of clay than just the kind shown here. This kind of mining - through deforestation - is quite harmful to the environment. Some issues that arise are erosion and destruction of habitats.
attributes.address: ES-220 - Barra de São Francisco - Espirito Santo, Brazil
attributes.title: Clay retrieval

attributes.description: Most of Faber-Castell's Production takes place in brazil. from what meager information I've been able to gather, workers in Brazil have a wide variety of work experiences. the poorest of the poor makes $80 a month, which is ridiculously low, as well as below Brazil's official minimum wake of $288 per month. The average wage is $680 per month. Without more data, I can only take an educated guess in saying that the workers here are average or slightly below for Brazil. They are much better off then workers in China though, and that I can say with certainty. Faber-Castell claims to be as eco-friendly as they can, by doing things like using water-based paint in their products. In the video I do see a LOT of machinery, which must use ridiculous amounts of energy. This factory is owned by Faber-Castell, which Is a multi-national company.
attributes.address: R. Cel. José Augusto de Oliveira Salles, 1876 - São Carlos - São Paulo, 13570-820, Brazil
attributes.title: Faber-Castell Factory, Brazil

attributes.description:
The founding point of Faber-Castell.
Most of their products were originally made in Germany, but now most of them are made in brazil.
attributes.title: Faber-Castell Headquarters
Staples (Point of Purchase)
attributes.description: I bought Faber-Castell pencils here. Workers are paid minimum wage (and probably get benefits, and all the other perks of being employed in the US) to start, so compared to the rest of the world, they're very well off.
